definitions.definition: Having no variations in height .
examples: The land around here is flat .

subdefinitions.definition: In a horizontal line or plane; not sloping .
examples: a flat roof

subdefinitions.definition: Smooth ; having no protrusions , indentations or other surface irregularities, or relatively so.
examples: The surface of the mirror must be completely flat .
The carpet isn't properly flat in that corner.
She has quite a flat face.

subdefinitions.definition: Having small or invisible breasts and/or buttocks .
examples: That girl is completely flat on both sides.

definitions.definition: Without variation in level, quantity, value, tone etc.
examples: The exchange rate has been flat for several weeks.

subdefinitions.definition: At a consistently depressed level; consistently lacklustre.
examples: Sales have been flat all year, and we've barely broken even.

subdefinitions.definition: Of fees, fares etc., fixed ; unvarying .
examples: a flat fee
flat rates
a flat fare on public transport
He delivered the speech in a flat tone.

subdefinitions.definition: Not diphthongal ; without variation in height or backness .
Without variation in tone or hue ( uniform ), and dull (not glossy ).
examples: The walls were painted a flat gray.

definitions.definition: Lacking liveliness or action ; depressed ; uninteresting ; dull and boring .
examples: The party was a bit flat .
The market is flat today as most traders are on holiday.
The dialogue in your screenplay is flat — you need to make it more exciting.

subdefinitions.definition: Lacking in depth , substance , or believability ; underdeveloped ; one-dimensional .
examples: The author added a chapter to flesh out the book's flatter characters.
subdefinitions.label_groups: authorship , figuratively , especially of a character

definitions.definition: Lowered by one semitone .
Of a note or voice, lower in pitch than it should be.
examples: Your A string is flat .

definitions.definition: Absolute ; downright ; peremptory .
examples: His claim was in flat contradiction to experimental results.
I'm not going to the party and that's flat .

definitions.definition: Deflated , especially because of a puncture .
labels: of a tire or other inflated object
definitions.label_groups: of a tire or other inflated object

definitions.definition: With all or most of its carbon dioxide having come out of solution so that the drink no longer fizzes or contains any bubbles .
Lacking acidity without being sweet .
Unable to emit power; dead .
Without spin; spinless .
Sonant ; vocal , as distinguished from a sharp (non-sonant) consonant.
Not having an inflectional ending or sign, such as a noun used as an adjective, or an adjective as an adverb, without the addition of a formative suffix; or an infinitive without the sign "to".
examples: Many flat adverbs, as in 'run fast', 'buy cheap', etc. are from Old English.

definitions.definition: Having a head at a very obtuse angle to the shaft .
Flattening at the ends.
Exact .
examples: He finished the race in a flat four minutes.

definitions.definition: Such that the tensor product preserves exact sequences . See Flat module on  Wikipedia. Wikipedia .
Such that its target , regarded as a module over its source , is flat (as above).
definitions.label_groups: algebra , ring theory , of a ring homomorphism

definitions.definition: Such that the induced map on every stalk is flat (as a map of rings).
definitions.label_groups: algebraic geometry , scheme theory , of a morphism of schemes

definitions.definition: Having little froth and little milk.
Foolish ; simple-minded.

secondary_definitions: Without variation in level, quantity, value, tone etc.
( figurative ) Lacking liveliness or action ; depressed ; uninteresting ; dull and boring .
( music , note ) Lowered by one semitone .
( music ) Of a note or voice, lower in pitch than it should be.
Absolute ; downright ; peremptory .
( of a tire or other inflated object ) Deflated , especially because of a puncture .
( of a carbonated drink ) With all or most of its carbon dioxide having come out of solution so that the drink no longer fizzes or contains any bubbles .
( wine ) Lacking acidity without being sweet .
( of a battery ) Unable to emit power; dead .
( juggling , of a throw ) Without spin; spinless .
( phonetics , dated , of a consonant ) Sonant ; vocal , as distinguished from a sharp (non-sonant) consonant.

( grammar ) Not having an inflectional ending or sign, such as a noun used as an adjective, or an adjective as an adverb, without the addition of a formative suffix; or an infinitive without the sign "to".
( golf , of a golf club ) Having a head at a very obtuse angle to the shaft .
( horticulture , of certain fruits ) Flattening at the ends.
( of measurements of time ) Exact .
( homological algebra , of a module ) Such that the tensor product preserves exact sequences . See Flat module on  Wikipedia. Wikipedia .
( algebra , ring theory , of a ring homomorphism ) Such that its target , regarded as a module over its source , is flat (as above).
( algebraic geometry , scheme theory , of a morphism of schemes ) Such that the induced map on every stalk is flat (as a map of rings).
( of coffee ) Having little froth and little milk.
( UK , slang , obsolete ) Foolish ; simple-minded.
